description.narrative: By 2020, relevant human rights monitoring mechanisms have increased capacity to monitor child rights violations and activate redress actions in line with international standards and good practices., which contributes to Data And Child Protection, Justice For Children, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Public Finance And Local Governance. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2020 CRM systems use solid evidence for policy-making, reporting and advocacy on child rights, and facilitate claiming and redress procedures for the CRs violated.

sector.narrative: Independent national child rights institution / ombudsperson

description.narrative: Justice, Law and Order policy, planning and administration

title.narrative: Turkey United Nations Development Assistance Framework
UNICEF Policy on Harmonized Approach to Cash Transfers to Implementing Partners
UNICEF Procedure on Harmonized Approach to Cash Transfers to Implementing Partners
UNICEF procedure for programme implementation partnerships
UNICEF Contract Awards through the UN Global Marketplace
Turkey 2020 Annual Report on Results for Children
UNICEF Tender Notices through the UN Global Marketplace

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2020, relevant human rights monitoring mechanisms have increased capacity to monitor child rights violations and activate redress actions in line with international standards and good practices.

description.narrative: Following UNICEF's advocacy and dialogue with various stakeholders, a Parliamentary sub-committee on the Rights of the Child was established in July. The Committee is mandated to monitor prominent child rights concerns in the country as well as to translate those concerns into legislative actions, where necessary. UNICEF has also supported the implementation of the Child Rights Strategy of the Ombudsperson Institution, adopted in 2018, through the development of new tools. UNICEF also continued supporting and cooperating with civil society actors for enhancing monitoring, advocacy and reporting of child rights violations. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:15/01/2020

title.narrative: Capacity (procedures, mechanisms, expertize) of Ombudsman Office, National Human Rights Institution (NHRI), the Parliament and networks of child rights civil society groups to monitor and report on child rights violations

baseline.value: Ombudsman Office, NHRI, Parliament and existing networks of child rights civil society groups have limited capacity to monitor and report on child rights violations

target.value: 2020:Ombudsman Office, NHRI, Parliament and networks of child rights civil society groups have key procedures, mechanisms and expertise in place

actual.value:
2019:The OI kickstarted implementation of the tools developed under its CR strategy and enhanced efforts to reach out children.
NGO networks, supported by UNICEF, separately submitted reports to CRPD and UPR.

baseline.value: Ombudsperson: 65 (as of second half of 2015) NEHRI: 0 from children, 0 from NGOs

target.value: 2020:81 for Ombudsperson (25% increase), NEHRI: 50 from children, 50 from NGOs

actual.value:
2019:436 in total: 435 complaints lodged directly by children and 1 by the NGOs.
Data from NEHRI is not available.
